questions.neutral: Is it always this quiet when you come in?

hobby.message: Analog photography survive another day in Stenograd?
Found any new political literature lately?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Quieter than most places lately. Not that I mind.
I tend to read—old literature, mostly—keeps me occupied.
Recent events make it hard to find the right atmosphere.
Some hobbies need silence, especially these days.
Quiet is good. Gives me space for my collection—banned books, political ones.
The onboarding footage everywhere makes people nervous, keeps crowds thin.
Lately, reading in public feels risky, even here.
Sometimes I bring a page to copy, but not tonight.
Everyone’s memories are closer to the surface after those broadcasts.
I prefer quiet; it suits my hobby—restoring banned political texts, mostly from before BCI.
Those onboarding videos stirred up some interest in old ideas lately.
Collectors trade pages under tables now, but it’s more dangerous.
I’ve spent hours mending pamphlets while the city replays its indoctrination.
It’s odd—public history makes private history feel sharper, somehow.
People ask about my books now, even strangers.
Silence works for me. I restore and memorize banned political literature—old charters, treatises, lost essays.
When the onboarding archives went public, demand for originals spiked overnight.
My quiet moments are spent stitching spines or reciting passages in my head.
Some texts resurfaced that I’d only heard rumors of—people brought them nervously, hands trembling.
The broadcasts made everyone question their place—and sent some hunting for the words that came before.
I’ve copied critical passages that might vanish if we’re not careful.
You don’t forget the thrill of piecing together something forbidden when the city itself is uncertain.
I seek out quiet to work on my real passion—rescuing and reciting banned political works.
Restoration is almost meditative. I’ve rebuilt pamphlets written during the first compliance trials.
Broadcasting those onboarding archives shook loose more than memories—it brought lost texts out of hiding.
Someone left a first-edition microfilm at my door last week—no note, just trust.
Evenings, I copy new finds by hand, making sure the city’s edits don’t erase our past.
I’ve memorized the Unofficial Charter lines, just in case hard copies disappear again.
The silence here lets me remember verses I dare not repeat at home.
Moments like this—books open, footage echoing outside—I realize how much history is buried under the surface of this system.
hobby_answer: Still whispering, yes. These days I keep things quiet.
Hard to focus with all the old footage flooding the city.
People are watching each other now. Makes collecting risky.
Pamphlets stay hidden out of necessity.
Better not say more here.
Whispering, when I can get away with it.
Harder lately, with the onboarding broadcasts everywhere.
Old texts look more dangerous when everyone’s remembering confessions.
Had to hide something yesterday—someone lingered by my door.
Even reading feels like exposure now.
I keep my archive close, just in case.
They keep whispering. The broadcasts make it impossible to ignore their voices.
Everyone’s reliving old compliance scripts. Suddenly my collection feels very contemporary.
I caught myself cross-referencing pamphlets with things I said in my onboarding.
Neighbors act curious, even nervous, about what counts as history now.
Hard to decide which titles are safe to even display.
The whole city feels like it’s studying for an exam no one assigned.
Makes collecting more urgent, oddly exhilarating.
Always whispering. I’ve memorized passages most people pretend never existed.
Since the footage leak, everything’s turned upside down for collectors like me.
Old manifestos feel alive again—people quoting lines they once denied knowing.
I reorganized my archive last night, just anticipating a knock or a search.
Had to build a quick false wall for the most volatile texts.
Sometimes it feels like the city’s memory extends only as far as the last headline.
It’s strange—being both terrified and thrilled every time I open a folder.
Never expected these texts to become currency for trust or suspicion.
Still whispering as ever—these books are like old companions, honestly.
My first confiscated pamphlet is still hidden inside volume three of the regulations manual.
The onboarding broadcasts forced half the block to remember what they signed—people forget, until the system reminds them.
I’ve spent hours comparing note margins from past collectors—trying to see who adapted, who resisted.
The fear is real: every knock on the door reads like a warning now.
There’s a kind of connection when you quote a forbidden text and someone finishes the line.
I’ve started archiving versions of onboarding scripts, too—there are differences they never explained publicly.
Sometimes I think the greatest risk isn’t exposure, but forgetting entirely.
The system wants us all to lose our place in the story. My hobby is a map back.
